metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Governing Body of Nalanda College & Ors.

facts.text: Nalanda College was founded by a private citizen in 1920.
It became a degree college in 1945 and was affiliated to the Bihar University in 1951.
In March 1953, Mr. D.P. Srivastava, a Government servant, was appointed its Principal but the Government withdrew him on February 4, 1958.
At an extraordinary meeting of the Governing Body held on February 23, 1958, the appellant was appointed Principal and the University was informed; he took charge on July 11, 1958.
At a meeting on July 27, 1958, the appointment of February 23, 1958 was confirmed.
On November 9, 1959, there was a change in the constitution of the Governing Body and respondent No. 2 became its Chairman.

At a meeting on January 31, 1960, the Governing Body reconsidered the proceedings of February 23, 1958, resolved to appoint a new Principal, and decided that the appellant should continue to act till a new appointment was made. Appellant was present as ex-officio member.
Appellant complained to the Vice-Chancellor of Bihar University and was advised by letter to watch and see what happens.
On May 14, 1960, the Governing Body resolved to advertise the post of Principal. Appellant was present.
On September 26, 1960, the Governing Body resolved to readvertise the post.
Some candidates including the appellant were interviewed; on December 18, 1960, Governing Body resolved to authorise the Chairman to make a selection from interviewed candidates.
President (respondent No. 2) appointed respondent No. 4 as Principal; he was Principal of another college in Bihar.
On April 18, 1961, appellant was asked to hand over charge to new appointee by May 6, 1961.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 challenging validity of respondent No. 4's appointment.

Respondents denied: resolution of Feb 23, 1958 invalid as did not consider other teachers for promotion; appellant's appointment never approved by Syndicate; appellant applied for post later and offered for interview.

Patna High Court (July 19, 1961) dismissed petition: appellant's appointment invalid (no Syndicate approval); decision to advertise not punishment/termination/demotion; no protest by appellant, submitted for selection; respondent No. 4's appointment valid and approved by University.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's appointment as Principal was valid and never terminated.
Whether the resolution rescinding or cancelling the February 23, 1958 resolution was illegal (not in agenda, void under University Statutes).
Whether the appointment of respondent No. 4 was invalid (must be by Governing Body, not delegated; not approved by University; appellant better candidate entitled under Art. 41b Statute XVI).
Whether University Statutes under s.20 University of Bihar Act have force of law and writ under Art. 226 can issue against Governing Body (legal right and duty).

petitioner_arguments.text: Any resolution rescinding Feb 23, 1958 illegal as not included in agenda and void under University Statute.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: University Statutes under University of Bihar Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: New Principal's appointment invalid: had to be made by Governing Body at meeting, power could not be delegated to President/Secretary; not approved by University; appellant better candidate entitled to promotion.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: University Statutes; Art. 41b of Statute XVI

respondent_arguments.text: Resolution of February 23, 1958 not valid as did not consider case of other teachers for promotion.
Appellant's appointment never approved by Syndicate as required.
Appellant applied for post after new resolutions and offered for interview, cannot approbate and reprobate/challenge legality.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide if Statutes have force of law or if writ under Art. 226 can issue against Governing Body.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assuming contention right (public body, public duty), no legal right shown in appellant enforceable by mandamus.

court_reasoning.text: All appointments by Governing Body; no person appointed/removed/demoted except per Rules, but appellant shown no right to appointment/reinstatement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No Article in Statutes gives appellant right to be appointed or reinstated.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held appellant's appointment invalid (no Syndicate approval); decision to advertise not punishment/termination/demotion (not under Arts. 7,8,9); no protest, submitted for selection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot challenge new appointment as his own invalid and new one valid/approved.

holdings.text: No legal right in appellant entitling mandamus for appointment or reinstatement.
Appellant's appointment invalid lacking Syndicate approval; new appointment valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for writ of mandamus filed under this; requires legal right and duty.

statutes_cited.name: University Statutes (Bihar University)
statutes_cited.relevance: Govern appointments, approvals, removals; appellant's lacked Syndicate approval per Art. 5; no right shown.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed. Court held unnecessary to decide if University Statutes have force of law or writ competency, as even assuming so, appellant showed no enforceable legal right to appointment or reinstatement under the Statutes.

key_quotes.text: In order that mandamus may issue... it must be shown that the Statutes impose a legal duty and the appellant has a legal right under the Statutes to enforce its performance.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines conditions for mandamus, central to dismissal.

key_quotes.text: the appellant has not shown that he has any right entitling him to get an order for appointment or reinstatement.
key_quotes.speaker: court
